Feature: Are there specific vocabularies for hunting or use in the presence of avoidance kin?
Is there ritual speech?
Does the ritual speech involve parallellisms, dual symbolic categories?
Comment: Se petang lol, ei lafining puil 'jalan di jalan yang bersih, menumpang kapal yang tinggi'  People from this clan have for a long time married with this other clan, meaning the road is clean and established.

Feature: Is the ritual language known by everyone (or just by traditional leaders)?
Comment: Just by leaders

Feature: Are there ritual songs?
Comment: Harang is a song to call people to come, it is sung in the night

Feature: Are there ritual dances?
Is the language of the ritual songs a language you understand?
Is the language of the ritual songs a foreign language?
Comment: Alor language in a song: Ikan gere kolana i 'ikan pergi/naik ke kolana'

Feature: Do women and men dance together?
Are there traditional ceremonies where men and women must be separated?
Comment: Only men sit and talk adat. Women serve (i.e. not join in) because their 'hawa' or spirit is hot.

Feature: Is there a ceremony relating to planting/harvesting?
Comment: Rituals still observed: when building a traditional house, when renovating the altar, when visiting other villages, during door opening (bride fetching)

Feature: Did your ancestors arrive in boats?
Comment: Speaker does not know where the origin is, but that ancestor first landed in Om Teil (next door mountain)

Feature: Does sacrifice involve feeding of ancestors?
Comment: To give food to the spirits of ancestors is called "na'a" but this is idolatry now. The food given was the best grains of red rice, a healthy chicken's hearth and liver.

Feature: Is there/are  there (a) ritual place(s)?
Comment: There must be an altar in every village and each altar must be built atop human heads so that it will be magic.

Feature: Did your ancestors arrive as sea animals? (shark, crocodile, turtle, dolphin)
Comment: Ancestors were human but in some stories the ancestors are said to come down from coconut trees, or grow/appear from the earth or fire. In one story he hid under some garbage and when it was burned it got to hot and he appeared. Adang from kokar believe their ancestors to be fish and so they don't eat red fish.

Feature: Is there a myth about the origin of the people?
Comment: Adang bang palola mitosnya leluhur berasal dari dalam tanah.Otvai: mitos dibikin supaya orang takut dari dia. Keluar dari dalam api.

Feature: Are there traditional religious leaders or specialists?
Comment: hada o tumo,

Feature: Are there traditional drinks, or stimulants?
Comment: tuak, drink made from the Enau tree, katema (type of corn).

Feature: Is there a traditional sacrifice place?
Comment: On the altar in the village

Feature: Are there rituals around birth?
Comment: When a bride is sent away to get married, she is given a carrying cloth together with a blessing. Some superstitions or prohibitions: Pregnant women are not allowed to leave the house at night, if she has to, she needs to carry a knife. There is a ritual concerning the cutting of the umbilical cord "apu he tato' " (cutting the cord). There is also apu he hi (cord comes off) about 2/3 days after the child is born. The woman needs to bathe in scalding water after birth, administered by the midwife/shaman that helped in the birthing process.

Feature: Are there rituals around death?
Comment: When someone dies, although people may already know about it, the family of the deceased must still visit every home to tell the news. If a man dies, they seek out the mother's family and give 1 mokok "o se ar tel o ave voa" (close the door, lift the ladder) so that there is no more debt to pay and he is freed. If the person dies in an accident, there must be a ritual to call his spirit back home "laman apor" (calling the spirit home). The shaman calls out certain words. At a funeral they bring pigs, chicken, goats and money. They sing ritual songs "tab lolo".

Feature: Are there seasonal rituals apart from planting and harvesting, for example is there a ritual to ask for rain? Or other rituals?
Comment: The ritual for planting is called "pepel". It is done to raise the spirits/morale of those planting and harvesting. After harvest there is a celebration "Ala baloi bate baloi" (new  corn, new grains) or new food. The first harvest is collected and cooked and eaten as a village. There is also a ritual to ask for rain where they scream very loudly to the gods. they also sacrifice pigs. This practise lasted till 1980s. In 1987 they renovated the altar and the "hawa" (spirit) were "panas" (hot) then.

Feature: Do women traditionally weave?
Comment: We know how to but we follow the styles from the coast (i.e. the women learn from the coast)

Feature: Is there traditional pottery?
Are there moko?
Comment: Many

Feature: Is it allowed to exchange the moko?
Are there people who make new moko?
Are there traditional music instruments?
Comment: Suling (bamboo flute), gong, tambur (animal skin), a' diding (bamboo gong)

Feature: Are there particular traditional music styles?
Comment: Perceives it the same as other parts of Alor

Feature: Do people use body paint or tattoo?
Comment: People used to have tattoos on their sleeves for aesthetic purposes. The needle used is ancient (bronze?)

Feature: Were teeth traditionally filed? (i.e. made shorter with a file)
Comment: Practise is called "afing pel". One uses a sharpening stone (used for knives)

Feature: Are there typical traditional haircuts?
Comment: men: long hair, put in bamboo and placed on top of head. "ok". Combed with a "dana" made from bamboo

Feature: Traditional piercings?
Comment: (Only) Girls have earholes

Feature: Are feathers or beads used as adornments?
Comment: Men wear it on their heads as a sign of masculinity

Feature: Is there traditional jewelry?
Comment: Men tie cloth on their foreheads "musala"

Feature: Is there special adornment used in rituals or ceremonies?
Comment: bronze bangles for the feet "alilin" for the arms "salak"

Feature: Is spatial organization divided into primary and secondary type?
Are there conceptual connections between spatial directions such as E+S / W + N with male/female, or with day/night, or with right/left?
Do adults in this village typically speak more than one local language?
Do children typically speak more than one local language?
Is it common in this village that husband and wife have different languages?
Comment: Adang only

Feature: Does a wife learn to speak the language of her husband?
Comment: Also for husband. People generally learn the language of the village

Feature: Does a husband learn to speak the language of his wife?
Comment: Also for wife

Feature: Do they communicate with a third language?
Comment: Indonesian

Feature: Do people traditionally hunt?
Comment: Bow and arrow, spear,

Feature: Do people traditionally fish in the sea?
Comment: Spear 'tombak'

Feature: Do people traditionally have animal husbandry?
Comment: Goat, chicken, pig. Horse=not anymore, cow=new/recent, wild buffalo=not anymore, never domesticated

Feature: Do people traditionally have agriculture?
Comment: his fields are 2-3km away from the village, the furthest is in pehelelang, 1 hour's walk into the middle of the mountain

Feature: Intensity of cultivation?
Comment: November is for planting, January/February is for weeding, April is for harvesting

Feature: Major crops?
Comment: Major crops: Corn, sweet potato/tubers (ubi). In June: Vanillin, July: Cloves, October-December: candlenut. December - January go to the fields to plant. April: corn, tubers, betelnut, coffee.

Feature: Are there clans?
Comment: There are 6 clans 1) matu lelang, 2) tafa lelang 3) kapitang lelang 4) di' lelang 5) marang lelang 6) ail lelang. Ail lelang is the biggest clan. The clan with the smallest number is di' lelang.

Feature: Are there moieties?
Comment: From clan 1) adang, lobang, lahalo, duka. From clan 2) duil, mail, bana, duka. From clan 3) ani,lahal, duil, abor, jaha da' il. From clan 4) suma', bail, beni. From clan 5) duka, lafuil, alelang. From clan 6) adang, beli, duka, peni. Names come from ancestors (before Christianity came in) e.g. afor beni

Feature: Is there a concept of 'house' (uma/rumah) that equals a descent group?
Are clans matrilineal
Are clans, subclans or lineages ranked
Comment: The highest ranked clan is Kapitang Lelang: Very close to the royal family and can meet the royal family directly. Their marga = ani , abor. This village (Otvai) belongs to the Kapitang Lelang clans. They are our lords. Matu Lelang >  Ou Lelang = descendants of slaves. Their marga = abor, mule. Within each clan, the lineage of the oldest holds the rights to lead the family. The descendants of the original people are more important than the foreigners, e.g. Ow Lelang. Kapitang>tafa>matu>di'>marang. Otvai is one village. these 5 live on one side, and Ail separate. Ail lelang used to be its own people, then it was brought together as Otvai.

Feature: Does every clan speak their own language?
Is real property (land) inherited?
Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Comment: The oldest child delegates the moving objects

Feature: Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Comment: Otvai was owned by a landlord. Now the people own it.

Feature: Are there inheritance rules?
Comment: Inheritance is for all, but men get more than women. The women might be given things by the parent when alive. But if not, the oldest will divide it.

Feature: Is land inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Is land inheritance patrilineal (sons)?
Is moveable property inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Is moveable property inheritance patrilineal?
Do all children inherit, sons and daughters alike?
Comment: Usually the eldest receives the most.

Feature: Do all children inherit, with daughters receiving less?
Comment: Girls get some but men get more.

Feature: Can newcomers aquire land or gardens?
Comment: The clan heads arrange it. Foreigners can buy land and build houses.

Feature: At what age should young people get married?
Comment: Above 25 for boys, above 18 for females. They usually find spouses before 30 (that's considered old). Youngest in the village to marry was 23 years (M), Youngest 18 (F). In the old times, men could marry (only allowed to marry) if they could hunt and build a house. For girls, if they could weave baskets and have cracks on the underside of their feet (walked a lot)

Feature: Are there marriage rules – specify in notes field
Comment: Satu marga tidak boleh kawin. Satu suku tidak boleh kawin. Zaman dulu orang tidak mau dengan orang ow lelang. Pendatang tidak ada tanah. Tidak mau jadi budak/hamba. Sekarang requirement: menghidupi istri (dan anak). Ibu yang penting bisa urus anak dengan baik.

Feature: Is there gift exchange between bride's and groom's sides?
Comment: In the city they exchange rings but this is not our culture, and not good.

Feature: Is there bride service?
Comment: When you come for your bride you bring 2 gong (called: buka puntu rumah) 1 gong to knock the door, 1 to open the door. If don't have the gongs to open the doors, you will be indebted for life to the bride's family. In the 60s the speaker's bride price was 13 moko and it required great effort to pay back "Mabuk bayar selesai"

Feature: Transfer of residence at marriage?
Comment: You build a house first and then get married. The bride follows the husband to the new home.

Feature: Marital residence with kin?
Comment: If you don't have a house you live with groom's parents first but you must build a house.

Feature: Are traditional marriages obligatorily exogamous?
If mother dies, who raises the children?
Comment: If father marries again, then they are raised with the stepmother.
Possible Values: 12:Father and his family.;10:Father and/or his family;11:Mother and/or her family

Feature: Does a man typically marry a woman of his mother's subclan?
Comment: There is this term: Istri rumah suami rumah, where your mother's older brother's child can marry your mother's child (you) hence wife of the house. This happens often here.

Feature: Does a woman typicaly marry a man of her father’s subclan?
Comment: This is not possible at all. E.g. If Hana is the daughter of Bpk Adang (Otvai), she cannot marry in the same clan.

Feature: Are there locality-based restrictions on marriage
Comment: Not in this village. In other kampung, you might not marry other villages. Taboo.

Feature: Was polygamy permitted
Comment: In the past, yes. There were more women? Now not at all (Christianity came in)

Feature: Was polyandry permitted?
Comment: No, unless the husband dies or is divorced

Feature: Is bridewealth paid by the groom's side to the bride's side
Comment: belis' = moko. In the past, the bride price was 13 moko by the male to the female. Right now the min=1 max=3 given to the female's family.  First, the groom prepares the moko, and gives it to the bride's family. The bride's family then accepts, along with a gong, tenun ikat, and livestock (pigs, goats, cows, chickens)

Feature: Is dowry paid by the bride's side to the groom's side
Comment: balas belis' = moring. It looks like a moko but has a lower value moko. This is given to the bridegroom's family. If not/Additionally, the bride's family may give a parcel of land to the bride. That land is called "oj avai" (small bucket + chalk) and given to be used with her husband. This is given along with other items such as plates, rice, cloth to carry children. The message here is "go and have children, and tell your children to come and war with me" (this is a blessing)

Feature: Are villages the typical settlement pattern?
Comment: Mostly permanent homes following city planning rules (e.g. do not block main roads)

Feature: Are dispersed solitary family homesteads the typical settlement pattern?
Comment: No, everyone stays here. Even the farmers stay here when their fields are far away. In the past they built small huts in the fields to stay for a night or two.

Feature: Are settlements permanent?
Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related women
Mean size of local communities?
Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related men?
Comment: Ail Lelang, meaning the men are related, all from the ail lelang clan.

Feature: Are villages/hamlets (traditionally) located on hill tops?
Comment: 600m above sea level

Feature: Are villages/hamlets (tradtionally) located on the shore?
Do villages have places or spaces for gatherings?
Comment: Mesbah. Usually in homes of the chief/ kepala adat. Pyramid shaped (rumah panggung).

Feature: Shape of (traditional) houses?
Comment: 3 levels, there are stairs inside the hut, with a pyramid roof (4 equal sides). There is an attic to keep food, moko and grains.

Feature: Floor level of traditional houses?
Comment: Bamboo walls and floors, roof is made from alang-alang. Raised platform from the ground.

Feature: Shape of roof of traditional houses?
Comment: pyramid with pillars on it

Feature: Is there an attic or loft in a traditional house?
Comment: Storage of e.g. corn, gading, etc.

Feature: Do leaders come from particular lineages?
Comment: Each clan has one chief/ketua adat and usually it is the eldest son. Hada o' aneng 'pemilik adat' owner of the tradition instructs the Hada o' tumo' 'tua adat' chief to speak on behalf of the clan.  Hada o' tumo does not have to be the eldest son/child

Feature: Are leaders non-hereditary?
Comment: Leadership is inherited by the descendants. If the eldest is not available or suitable there can be replacements from the 2nd child or from the eldest (woman).

Feature: Are there groups with whom traditional relations are forbidden?
Are there groups with whom there has been war?
Comment: Long time ago, there were head hunters but it ended in the 1800. A new King arrived (Bau Lolong. Alor Besar's king) and formed relations between the villages.

Feature: Is there an opposition between people of the interior and people of the shore?
Comment: There are Adang people living in Kokar (by the sea). There is no difference.

Feature: Are there female community/clan leaders
Are there men’s houses
Comment: Rumah adat belongs to men to sit and talk about adat. (women sit behind or outside)

Feature: Are there (traditional)   rulers/kings?
Comment: Setiap wilayah ada raja (adat) and it is passed on hereditarily. Aven Lelang (=suku raja)

Feature: Are there slaves?
Comment: aho' atiting 'slave'. In traditional rituals (parties, rituals, house building) this practise can exist. But not in daily life. These were often newcomers or those whose ancestors are not known and not part of the clan and therefore have no rights. They were Abui. And in our eyes Abui was lower. They can be caught and sold, to those who want them. Hereditary.  E.g. when a couple has no children they can ask to raise a child. Speaker's grandmother practised it but not anymore.

Feature: Is there a concept for both ruler and foreigner, stranger king?
Comment: Foreigner will also be king "aven" but doesn't say if foreign or not. Just assumed.

Feature: Are there traditional relations/alliances with one or more neighbouring groups?
Comment: A treaty made in the 1800 dictate that 10 villages in Adang, 3 in Alor and 7 in Pura can never fight each other. The treaty was sealed in blood, and they are seen as related by blood.

Feature: Is there a special name for this alliance?
Comment: Bel basa. "sumpah bela baja". adang bang hernu, pul bang itito, ail bang tou. (Adang 10 kampung, Alor 3 kampung, pura 7 kampung) cannot not fight. They swore, drinking blood on the altar. Latalah 'god' in the sky was called. If you break this oath you die (vomit blood).

Feature: Is namesake ritually marked, or with features reminiscent of particular kinship relations?
Comment: When you are born you are immediately given a name by your father or grandparents. Your mother cannot give you a name. There are 2 names: Christian and Adang. The muslim Adang also have their version of their sarani (Christian) names. Your Adang name is given by your father or grandparents "tua". The informant's Adang name is Mule. Usually a baby cries incessantly and families call it several names until he stops crying when called that particular name. Other eg. Sanadi 'opa di alor kecil'
Possible Values: 10:Given Abui name upon birth given by  parents;0:No;1:Yes

Feature: Do descent groups own sets of personal names?
Comment: Adang name: If you are called Lamhal you are almost certainly from the Aven Lelang clan.

Feature: Are names taken from the father's group?
Comment: Sarani or adang (men's family chooses).

Feature: Are names taken from the mother's group?
Are there name taboos?
Comment: Adang names: You cannot give names of criminals (e.g. people who murdered or stole) or names associated with them.

Feature: Are there particular relations not to be addressed, or mentioned, by name
Comment: Children cannot call their superiors by their names (general principle going up)

Feature: did your language (or a group of people defined by speaking the language) traditionally have a name, other than a locality name
Is there a special word to refer to a foreigner?
Comment: nameho 'orang datang'
